### Question 2

```{r}
library(purrr)
library(readr)

# Specify the directory where your CSV files are located
directory_path = "/Users/cindytseng/Desktop/p8105_hw5_ht2607/data"

# List all CSV files
csv_files_df =
  list.files(directory_path, pattern = "\\.csv$", full.names = TRUE)

# Create a dataframe to store filenames
file_df =
  data.frame(filename = csv_files_df)

# Use purrr to read data for each subject
file_df <- file_df |> 
  mutate(data = map(filename, ~ read.csv(.x)))

# Extract subject ID and arm from filenames
file_df <- file_df |> 
  mutate(
    subject_id = str_extract(filename, "\\d+"), # Extract numerical subject ID
    arm = str_extract(filename, "con|exp") # Extract arm information
  )

# Unnest the data and select relevant columns
exp_con_tidy_df <- file_df |> 
  select(subject_id, arm, data) |> 
  unnest(data)

# Rename columns for clarity
colnames(exp_con_tidy_df) <- c("Subject_ID", "Arm", "Week", "Observation")

# Make sure "Week" and "Observation" are in appropriate data types (e.g., numeric)
# Extract and assign the "Week" and "Observation" columns using pull
exp_con_tidy_df <- exp_con_tidy_df |> 
  select(Week, Observation) |> 
  mutate(
    Week = as.numeric(Week),
    Observation = as.numeric(Observation)
  )

# Create a spaghetti plot
ggplot(exp_con_tidy_df, aes(x = Week, y = Observation, group = subject_id, color = Arm)) +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "Spaghetti Plot of Longitudinal Data",
       x = "Week",
       y = "Observation",
       color = "Arm") +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

```
